docTitle.titlePart:
Real-time FPGA-based Coherent Optical Receiver for
1 Gsymbol/s, 64 QAM Transmission

byline.docAuthor: Masato Yoshida, Tatsunori Omiya, Keisuke Kasai, and Masataka Nakazawa

byline.affiliation: Research Institute of Electrical Communication, Tohoku University,

front.div:
Abstract: We demonstrated the first time real-time FPGA-based coherent optical receiver for a 64
QAM transmission. Error free performance (BER < 1x10
-12 ) was achieved under a back-to-back
condition and the BER after transmission was measured on-line.
front.reference: OCIS codes: (060.1660) Coherent communications; (060.2330) Fiber optics communications
front.div:
1. Introduction
Coherent multilevel optical transmission has been receiving a lot of attention with respect to expanding the
transmission capacity in a finite optical amplification bandwidth. In particular, quadrature amplitude modulation
(QAM) has an advantage as regards increasing the spectral efficiency (SE). Recently, total WDM transmission
capacities of 69.1 and 64 Tbit/s transmission have been reported using 16 and 36 QAM formats with SEs as high as
6.4 and 8 bit/s/Hz, respectively [1,2]. We have also demonstrated 256 and 512 QAM transmissions that achieved
SEs exceeding 10 bit/s/Hz [3,4]. However, previous QAM transmission experiments were based on off-line
processing. The development of a real-time coherent optical receiver for multi-level QAM signals is an important
issue if we are to realize highly spectral efficient optical transmission systems.
Recently, a real-time coherent optical receiver for QPSK signals beyond 40 Gbit/s [5-7] and a 6.67 Gbit/s OFDM
signal with a 16 QAM modulation format [8] have been demonstrated. Since it is difficult to completely compensate
for phase error in homodyne or heterodyne detection with a real-time digital signal processor (DSP), a real-time
receiver for a coherent optical signal with a multiplicity of more than 32 has not yet been reported. In this paper, we
demonstrate the first real-time FPGA-based coherent optical receiver for a 64 QAM transmission with an optical
phase-locked loop (OPLL) technique. Error free performance (bit error rate (BER) < 1 x 10
-12 ) is achieved under a
back-to-back condition. In this experiment, 6 Gbit/s data can be demodulated with four 1 GS/s analog to digital
converters (ADCs), and a data bit rate to ADC sampling rate ratio of 6 bit/sample can be achieved.
